title: Can magic spells actually work? - Quora

response.answer_text: In a classically scientific sense, the answer is no. When magick spells results have been tested in the laboratory it is routinely limited to ‘seeing’ the designs on an unseen card-face. Invariably the results with Witches are a few percentage point better than simply guessing. That said, I would like you to consider, if you will, a very personal scenario from my life story as ‘my evidence’ that magick spells do indeed work nowadays for those with the innate abilities and the proper training and degrees. to wit: Storm and Rowan When I was 15 1/2, in 1967, I went to my first High School dance and it was not working for me! So I was walking across the dance floor to leave and suddenly, sitting on a bench was a gorgeous Goddess of a girl. Without a thought I walked up and asked her to dance. She looked up and said said ‘Sure!’ Her name was Janene. The look in her gorgeous Scandinavian and Scottish blue eyes was magickal! I took her hand, and led her to the dance floor, and I said to myself ‘Oh My God, I have just met my wife!’ Well, we became an item and we dated, danced, went to nice restaurants and enjoyed the Berkeley-San Francisco area together for the next year and some. In that time our two abusive and controlling mothers had developed a huge hate for one-another and they forced us apart in a very draconian and coordinated fashion. We were each told fictional lies about the other and forbidden to see each other. In time she went her way and I mine. We each married and divorced. After my 2nd divorce, I lived in Seattle and had found Wicca or perhaps Wicca had found me! I had read several of the works of the wonderful Raymond Buckland, so I had a solid foundation for ‘The Wiccan Way’. Then, one day, I laid hands on Sally Morningstar’s amazing and life altering book, ‘The Wiccan Way!’ Suddenly, I had a clear vision of what it all meant, and my life was forever changed. I learned about the heart, soul and ethics of Wicca. I came to embrace the Wheel of The Year and The Seasons of the Witch. Following Sally Morningstar’s ‘The Wiccan Way’ with format from Raymond Buckland’s ‘The Tree - The Complete Book of Saxon Witchcraft’ I wrote my Wiccan Dedication Ritual. Then under a full Autumn’s Moon, along the shore of the Skykomish River, north of Seattle, I dedicated myself and my life to my Goddess, My God and to Wicca! As a hereditary Witch with ties to Scotland, Wales and France and with a talent for Storm Magick, I took the name ’Storm Wynd’ At the end of my Ritual, I somehow had the audacity to ask the Goddess for a visit with with my long lost Janene of days long past. The next morning I brewed my Starbucks coffee and loaded my things into the car for the drive home. I had gone perhaps a quarter mile, when there was the intense smell of the Autumn forest, like incense! The air in the car was charged as during an electrical storm. Suddenly the Goddess was there with me! She was like an apparition and her eyes periodically changed from one racial type to another. I was emotionally blown away and began talking to her, babbling one might say. However, I managed to again ask about Janene. In a few minutes she was gone and I was left crying and very much alone! The next morning, I arrived at work and was given a request to perform a Quality Audit at a company in Fountain, Colorado near Colorado Springs. A week later I arrived at my Hotel in Colorado Springs and unpacked, then went to dinner. Back at the Hotel television was a waste. So, having an unusual French name, I looked in the telephone book for the family name, but no luck. Then for reasons I can’t identify, I flipped to her name. Suddenly before my eyes was her brother’s name and number. I called, and he remembered me and we reminisced a little and I asked about his sister. He replied, ‘Well, you might not want to hook up with her because, she’s a Witch'. I replied, ‘Really, so am I’! He gave me her number in Texas!!! When I got back to Seattle, I held a ritual to thank the Goddess for this opportunity to at least connect. I shopped for groceries at the Pike Place Market and walked across the street to the Pike Place Wine Shop for a bottle of Shira and drove home to my condo in Kent which overlooked the Green River. I made dinner and had a nice glass of wine and finally, not being able to delay the inevitable any longer, I dialed the numbers into the telephone. Suddenly, I am talking to HER, and her Wiccan name is Rowan Stormdancer! WOW! We talked, cried and laughed for four hours and I invited her to Seattle. A week later I waited impatiently for her plane at Seatac. My long, long wait was over and she was in my arms. We were soon Handfasted in Colorado Springs for our engagement and later again in Texas where we jumped the broom for our wedding. I am 66 and retired and we have a townhouse condo in Colorado Springs and it’s a great life to be a Wiccan Witch! It turns out that both of our families fought against the British at Culloden and the families were ultimately exiled! If you look closely at the attached picture of us, taken at my step-daughter’s wedding, you will see Rowan’s aura around her head and spilling around her shoulders! Blessed Be! Kind of a funny story. Lol. Oh, but we got a good laugh out of it… See, my son (who is 18) was living with his dad and going to high school in Texas. So, my daughter and I went to his graduation late spring (May). A few months later (August), now that school ended and he graduated he wanted to move back home. Of course! thumbs up. Soooo, I haven’t seen him in a few months. I go to the airport to pick him up and the first thing he says is how much longer my hair is and how he’s trying to grow his out…blah blah blah. “So mom,” he says, “how do you get your hair to grow so quickly?” I said, “Well, I take care of it… deep condition weekly, take biotin…” And he was like, “oh okay… I can to do that.” I said, “Well, that’s fine but, you know… I actually also did a magic spell on my hair…seriously kid, no lie.” He looked at me and just laughed and said, “Yea whatever, mom.” I said, “No no…cross my heart. Every night before bed, I’d grab a piece of my hair in my hand and I would say these words: Stretch it, twist it, make it grow… Like a river, let it flow… Three times fast shall this hair grow… This is my will, so mote it be…” He laughed some more. I did too. But, then he looked at me all serious and was like, “Uh, really?” I said, “Yes, just do that three times a night before bed and your hair will grow super fast! You’ll see.” Inside I was just dying, cause man…what the hell? is he that gullible I was thinking? Poor kid. Uh, he’s definitely been living with his dad. So obvious….ha ha. He needs to move back home and we need to straighten him out. Anyways, fast forward, I was about to go to bed that night when my son comes running in my room and says, “Mom, mom…tell me that spell again…so I can get my hair to grow…” I told him the words, and he grabbed a piece of his hair and three times said that little chant. I was trying so hard not to roll my eyes and laugh. I thought, I am just going to go with it. And damn, he was actually doing it and believing it. ha ha. God, I am so mean. Fast forward again to next morning…my son comes running in my room, “Mom, mom…did it grow? Is it longer?”, he asked as he is checking his hair out in on my dresser mirror. “Really? “, I say, “ It’s going to take longer than one night…” “Oh, how long?”, he questioned. “Give it a week…”, I state. Soooo, yea, every damn night he would religiously hold on to his hair and chant: Stretch it, twist it, make it grow… Like a river, let it flow… Three times fast shall this hair grow… This is my will, so mote it be…” Sheesh & OMG. (face palm) Finally, after about 8 days, I am sitting at the kitchen table talking to my daughter when my son comes storming down the stairs… “Mom, mom… this is just not working. My hair is not any longer at all. Look at it, do you think so?” I just stared at him like completely dumbfounded. My daughter was like, “What? What the hell are you talking about? What is going on?” I looked at her and shook my head. Smiled. He says, “Mom told me that her hair grows so fast cause she did that magic spell…” She looks at me questioningly… I said, “You know, that one….Stretch it, twist it, make it grow…Like a river, let it flow…Three times fast shall this hair grow…This is my will, so mote it be…” She rolls her eyes at me, “No… you did not?” she says, “and brother you are such an idiot…”, getting up from the table…pointing at me, ”…her hair hasn’t grown that quickly, she has frigging extensions… omg you seriously have been doing this spell? for a week? Good god.” She looked at me like is this a joke… I said, “Nope.” We just laughed and laughed. sighs. Yes, my hair magically went from 16 inches to 22 inches in two months…I wish… Well we thought it was super funny. Poor kid though and damn he fell for another one just a few days later in regards to money. He says, “Mom mom, I need money.” I said, “well, do some magic…” and laughed. I was sure he’d laugh and be like, yea not falling for that one again. But noooooo. He says, “ OK what do I have to do? What’s the chant? the spell?” Eye twitches. What the…? God, I am bitch. But, its so fun. I said, “okay…”, all excited… “We have to light a green candle for this one…” He was like, “Where is there a green candle?” I said, “look over there in that drawer…” And wallah, he finds a box with all different sorts of colored candles… (hehe cause yea, I am not a witch…gah…*gives wave of my hand* I don’t know about this stuff… I just keep a box of spell candles on hand…cause you never know…coughs) I tell him to grab a green candle and a rune stone. “A what?”, he says… “A rune stone…” I repeat, pointing to a bowl on the table. I was just messing with him. God. As he’s searching for a lighter for the candle, I quickly look up “Simple Money Spell” on Pinterest. sighs and laughs. Back to the previous eve… my daughter had some friends over, so my son and I were upstairs in the loft watching a movie… kind of staying out of their way. Well, I guess when he was sitting on the couch, a bunch of quarters fell out of his pocket. When I saw them there the next morning I picked them up but, my hands were full as I was carrying laundry basket, too. I go into my room… laundry basket in my arms and a handful of quarters clenched in my fist. I plop the laundry basket on the bed, to fold and sort, and kind of just place the quarters on the bed next to the basket thinking I will bring those downstairs later. And well, yea, I forgot about the quarters. I make the bed, not realizing I just threw the comforter over a small pile of quarters. So, back to that night…I am sitting on my bed and I tell him to write how much money he wants on the side of the green candle… then I tell him to light the candle and say this chant… Money money come to me… In abundance three times three… May I be enriched in the best of ways… harming none, on its way… This I accept, so mote it be… Bring me money three times three…” then I tell him to run the rune stone through the flame three times and place rune in your wallet. Thumbs up! all set. He reaches into his pocket for his wallet, and puts the rune stone in there. He says to me, “how long does it take?” I said, “ I don’t know… you have to do it for three nights straight…” He says, “Okay, cool…” and I suddenly remember the quarters under the blanket. evil laugh. He’s about to walk out of the room, I say, “hey, I hear spirit…” He says, “what? Wth?” I say, “yea he is saying money has been sent to you…look on bed, under the blanket…” I look at my son and I point to corner edge to bed…”lift that side of the blanket…do you see anything?” OMG his face just goes pale…and he falls to floor, clutching his belly…laughing like in shock…”No way, No way, No way…” he keeps saying. “haha” I was laughing cause he was just rolling…”what is so funny?”, I say… He says, “look at the bed…”, pointing to corner and pile of quarters….”what the hell is this trippy shit??” I say, “Omg it worked…” and we were laughing so hard, my daughter comes in…”what the hell is so funny?????” arms crossed, but with a smile on her face. I say, “Your brother did a magic spell for money… and look….”, pointing to all the quarters. She looks at me shaking her head and looks at her brother, “are you really that stupid? You really believe this sh!T?” “Hey…”, I yell at her…”be nice”… she laughs and pushes her brother…”omg what is wrong with you?”, she says… He looks at me, puts his head in his hands, “Omg you are messing with me again!” I laughed, “yea those are the quarters that fell out of your pocket the other night…” hahahahahaha. “Seriously, though…”, I say, “Keep the green stone in your wallet. It will attract money.” “Oh my god, you are so mean…” but he is laughing at himself. His sister laughing at him. Man, we have fun though. We do stuff like this to each other all the time. Ahhh but we have fun.

Yes. No. Maybe so. Spellwork is very unpredictable. Can it work? … sure. Does it always work, every single time? … nope. Is there any way to guarantee that it will work in any particular instance? … again, nope. At its most basic, magic is simply manifesting a desired goal or change through force of will. This is something that most people do, without realizing it, on a daily basis. We formulate a goal and we make it happen. In terms of spellwork, it’s simply a matter of doing it in a slightly different way. Like anything else in life, there are many variables that impact whether or not a spell manifests the way that we want it to. A few points to consider: First and foremost, magic cannot defy the laws of nature/physics. So things like sprouting wings, or transforming into some other being, are not something that are possible through spells.Focus and clarity when working the spell – left unguided, magic will work in its own way and in its own time. So a vague, “money to me on the wind” (for example) could mean that you find a lost $5 bill in your pocket, rather than an actual sum of money that helps your financial situation improve. So be clear and concise when forming the intent of the spell, especially if you need specific help with something.Magic is not like what we see on TV or in the movies – there is no snap your fingers and POOF. Manifesting a spell takes work, and in general, doing something mundanely is infinitely easier than doing it magically. So (again using a money spell as an example) if you are expecting to recite a few words and suddenly have money rain down on your head – while it’s not completely impossible, it would be very unlikely unless you first play the lotto, or (even better) take some other concrete steps towards improving your financial situation, such as applying for loan/grant, looking for a job, or some other sort of fundraising.So it definitely has the potential to work, but as mentioned previously, nothing is ever guaranteed. But the way I see it, can’t hurt to try.

I've thought a lot about what is classified as magic and what is classified as science. Magic is essentially what 'science' has rejected. What science is, is commonly misunderstood. It is essentially a practice of doubt, as there is no faith whatsoever. Scientists read what people have written and constantly run tests to either prove or disprove each other. If one day the entire internet suddenly vanished, every research paper ever written burned up, and every scientist forgot what had been proven and what hadn't or essentially we had to prove everything all over again, magic and science would be one and the same. It's only when the research actually starts up again does the magic get picked from the proven. You would actually be surprised how much of what we understand about magic can attributed to psychology and confirmation bias. Someone could tell you that due to your astrological sign, your tarot cars readings, your residual tea leaves, or the lines on your palm that something very lucky will come your way. Shortly after you trip down the stairs you find a penny. It worked! Super lucky penny! Proven! Or they could tell you miss fortune is coming your way. You trip down the stairs before finding a penny. It worked! Owie stairs! Proven! This is my interpretation of this. Of course if you've heard this explanation before a thousand times and still believe this, then say hello to the backfire effect, “…a cognitive bias that causes people who encounter evidence which challenges their beliefs to reject that evidence, and to strengthen their support of their original stance.” (The Backfire Effect: Why Facts Don’t Always Change Minds). This means that facts against a viewpoint can cause people to shrug them off and solidify their own confidence in the viewpoint, which, as you may have noticed, goes hand in hand with the Dunning-Kreuger Effect. For a personal anecdote, I met someone who claimed to be a Wiccen (I only heard it pronounced…). He believed it wholeheartedly, carried around a wand, spell books, and he told me all about how it works. I was interested because I am a enthusiast of magic within fiction and wanted to hear what his interpretation of magic was, and I wanted to figure out where the evidence that convinced him was. Who knows, if something has you convinced that you can do magic it must be pretty solid. The way he described it, you had to meditate for many years, understand the intricacies of each spell and you could perform it with a lot of practice, and you had to believe it really really strongly. He tried to show me but, to my disappointment his explanation to why I couldn't see it was because I wasn't believing hard enough. So it definitely might've been an emperor with no clothes deal. He also claimed it was a family thing and it wasn't just him. So me, being curious, asked his sister about it. She litterally waved it off with a “pfft.” I didn't really know how to interpret that aside from her making it clear that she believed it was hooey. Enjoy!

There is a misconception that somehow we impose our will on God or the universe or other people via simply asking for it, a la prayer. That’s not how it works, and that’s not, in my experience, what happens. How many red lights have I pointed my finger at and said, “Change” with no change occurring? How many times have I hoped for a different outcome in my relationships at work, only to find that no, people are indeed, still the same, despite my silent pleadings? How often have I wanted something so badly that I was desperate for any solution, only to have God tell me no! And why? Because prayer works to align yourself with divine will. It’s like Jesus said in Gethsemane: “Not my will, but thine, be done.” Our job in prayer is to humble ourselves to the point that we accept that will as our own, thereby changing our carnal desires to be in line with God’s righteous ones. Only then do we gain peace and comfort, knowing that God’s got it handled and is eager to bless us in the ways we now see that we need, rather than our selfish wants from before. It’s true that most of us do not approach God in the humble, teachable way that I’m describing. Nearly every pleading for the pain or violence to stop lacks this subtlety and patience. And there have been times, in my extremity, when I have cried out for physical salvation and, in His good grace, God has seen fit to answer with aid, immediately. But even then, I find that I had resigned myself to His will, even in that moment of desperation. So I pray and learn to time the stop lights so that when I point at them next time, they do change—not because I have exerted power over them, but because they no longer exert power over me. I’ve learned to be patient with my fellow man and understand that we are all traveling life’s journey at our own pace. I’ve learned to accept “No” as an answer, even when the reason is not immediately apparent. All this learning has made me a better, calmer, more peaceful man, full of hope, and confident in my God. That’s how prayer works for me.

Magic is not a "magic pill" that will instantly solve all your problems, and attract all your desires instantly. That being said... Magic does work, and it can change your life. Here's how... First understand that Magic is a way to "engage" the power of your mind, spirit, soul, and subconscious. When you do it correctly, not only does it invoke the power of positive thinking in your mind... but it creates a subconscious drive to achieve what you want. Yes...there are mystical forces at work in the universe that can help the spell get the result you want... but even more powerful is what happens inside of you. To do this...to cast a successful spell requires just 5 things. That's it. 5. If you "get these right" there's no end to what you can accomplish with Magic. Thing #1: Emotional Attachment It is important to allow yourself to feel full emotion for the desire you're trying to attract. The more emotion you feel and build into the spell, the better your results. Do whatever you have to do in order to evoke your strongest emotions. Thing #2: Belief You must believe in Magic with all your heart... even more you must believe that the spell you are going to cast will help you achieve the results you desire. Thing #3: Focus You must remain focused on only the single desire at hand. I never recommend trying to cast a spell to satisfy more than 1 desire at a time. You must focus on 1 thing, and 1 thing only during your spell. Thing #4: Mundane Effort Once you cast a spell, don't sit around "waiting" for it to bring results. You must start taking real action on your own that will bring you closer to the goal or desire. If you cast a love spell, for example, get out of the house...make an effort to smile and engage people. Give the spell a chance to work! Thing #5: Let It Go Don't obsess on "when" the spell will bring results... or how quickly things will start to change. It's best for you to simply forget about the spell, and move on with your life in a positive way. If you continue to think, think, think, you'll hold back some of the energy from the spell. Follow these 5 Magic Keys every time you cast a spell and I know you'll find success. :)

Yes, they do. Actually people use magic spells for their own selfish goals and not to help others. But I will tell you one real life incident where a tantrik used white magic spell to save a child. I heard this years back from an acquaintance of mine. A worried mother once visited the chamber of a renowned tantrik. Her only son was waning day by day for no specific illness. No doctor had been able to diagnose any disease, yet the boy was getting thinner and weaker with each passing day. The mother was extremely worried that if nothing was done promptly to cure the child then he would die soon. The tantrik wanted to see a photograph of the child. When he looked at the photo he turned pale. He said that a death spell had been cast on the boy and that he was going to die the following new moon day, which was the very next day. The mother cried bitterly and requested the tantrik to save her only child. The tantrik took pity on her and promised to save her boy. He asked her to light a diya near the head of the boy the following night. The diya was to remain lighted throughout the night and should not go out at any cost for a single second. If she managed to do that, then her child would be saved. Next evening, the parents of the ailing boy lit a big diya near his head and patiently sat beside him. The diya had enough oil and a big, fat wick to last through the night. It was the month of January and all the doors and windows were tightly closed. These was no passage for any air to enter the room. Apart from the diya, a big candle was also kept burning nearby. Just when the clock struck twelve, a very strange thing happened. The diya suddenly went out. The alert mother immediately lit it again with the help of the burning candle. The night passed quietly without any further incident. The boy started recovering from the next day. He completely recovered within a few days. The following week, the thankful mother again visited the tantrik to express her gratitude towards him. What the tantrik said in reply shocked her. He said that one of her husband's closest relatives had come to him earlier. It was according to her wish that he himself had cast the death spell on the boy. That was why he knew exactly when the boy was going to die. But after seeing the aggrieved mother, he felt repentant (he himself had a boy of the same age) and decided to save the boy with the help of white magic. Positive Therapeutic Effects of Intercessory Prayer in a Coronary Care Unit Population Cardiac patients from the San Francisco General Medical Center were randomly divided (using a computer-generated list) into two groups. The names of the patients in the "test" group were given to a group of Christians, who prayed for them while they were in the hospital. The intercessory prayer team members were chosen on the following basis: Born again Christians on the basis of John 3:25Led an active Christian life on the basis ofdaily devotional prayerfellowship in a local Christian churchMethodThe "placebo" group received no prayer. Neither the "test" nor the "placebo" group of patients knew if they were receiving prayer. Likewise, the hospital staff, doctors, or nurses were "blinded" since they did not know which patient belonged to which group. ResultsStatistics were acquired from the prayer and placebo groups both before and after prayer, until the patients were discharged from the hospital. There were no statistical differences between the placebo and the prayer groups beforeprayer was initiated. The results demonstrated that patients who were prayed for suffered "less congestive heart failure, required less diuretic and antibiotic therapy, had fewer episodes of pneumonia, had fewer cardiac arrests, and were less frequently intubated and ventilated." Statistics demonstrated the the prayer group had a statistically significantly lower severity score based upon the hospital course after entry (p < 0.01). Multivariate analysis of all the parameters measured demonstrated that the outcomes of the two groups were even more statistically significant (p < 0.0001). In science, the standard level of significance is when a "p value" is less than 0.05. A value of 0.01 means that the likelihood the result is because of chance is one in 100. A p value of 0.0001 indicates that in only one study out of 10,000 is the result likely to be due to chance. Table from the study is reproduced below. The remarkable thing which one notices is that nearly every parameter measured is affected by prayer, although individually many categories do not reach the level of statistical significance due to sample size. However, multivariate analysis, which compares all parameters together produces a level of significance seldom reached in any scientific study (p < 0.0001). The author points out that the method used in this study does not produce the maximum effect of prayer, since the study could not control for the effect of outside prayer (i.e., it is likely many of the placebo group were prayed for by persons outside of the study). It is likely that a study which used only atheists (who had no Christian family or friends) would produce an even more dramatic result. However, since atheists make up only 1-2% of the population, it would be difficult to obtain a large enough sample size.    More on that research here:Hodge, D.R. 2007.
